summary: This is a press release from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York announcing the death of Jeffrey Epstein by apparent suicide in his cell at the Manhattan Correctional Center. The statement reaffirms the office's commitment to its ongoing investigation into sex trafficking of minors and urges victims to come forward.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Issued the official statement on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office announcing Jeffrey Epstein's death and reaffirming the ongoing investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The accused who was found dead in his cell at the Manhattan Correctional Center from an apparent suicide while facing federal sex trafficking charges.

connections.description: Berman, as the U.S. Attorney, was the lead federal prosecutor overseeing the criminal case against Epstein.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Manhattan Correctional Center and was pronounced dead shortly thereafter of an apparent suicide.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide in his cell at the Manhattan Correctional Center on the morning of August 10, 2019.
Epstein was facing federal charges brought by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York for sex trafficking of minors, which included a conspiracy count.
The U.S. Attorney's Office stated its investigation into the conduct charged in the indictment remains ongoing despite Epstein's death.
The statement is directed at Epstein's victims, urging them to come forward and contact the FBI.
The document frames Epstein's death as a potential hurdle to providing victims their day in court.
